comments.commentBody: You've got that right!

Mr. Walker, what you ask is that our nation becomes "The States of America."  There's nothing at all "United" about much of what the GOP proposes nor the man the GOP blindly and foolishly supports in the White House.  One can only hope that Trump is NOT the ventriloquist's dummy sitting in the lap of the oligarchs, including Putin, that he appears to be.  I'll listen more when the GOP moves the mannequin's mouth so that "United" is back in the act.

Be afraid. It sounds rational, but it drips with hypocrisy and a dangerous alternate view of reality in the here and now. Perfect for the age of Trump. Stand strong against protest. It's time Mr Walker has a remedial lesson in U.S. history. It's time he looked around and saw how authoritarian governments around the world handle protest by their citizens. Is that what he advocates for the U.S.? Well if there were any question, at least we know the true Republican state of mind, and why they have been silent on T's excesses. We should feel sorry for the Republicans because people are being mean to them. They're turning into little Trumps. Be afraid.

The Times gave him a "voice" BUT the People remind its readers how vilified this governor has been.

Who had to drop out first of all the GOP candidates? Walker!

Who was followed everywhere by protestors before he dropped out? Walker!

Who fells left out of this misbegotten DC sinking ship? Walker!

Whose underwater favorability is equal to trump? Walker?

Johnson started the war on poverty 50 years ago. It didn't work.

Republicans have had the same 50 years to fix poverty. Why didn't they?

As for health care, it is pretty obvious that Republicans don't care about people without healthcare.

But the real problem nobody is addressing is that we pay twice as much for health care as other industrialized countries such as Denmark or Germany or Sweden.

If we paid what they paid, we could have universal coverage and still have money left over to give every one two years of post high school education.

When it comes to ways to subvert the American democracy, this governor is admittedly an expert. He writes about "standing to fight for taxpayers," but the facts point in a rather different direction.

What Republicans really need to do right now is stop accommodating radical voices of those like those of Walker and his cronies. Republicans must prove that they are American enough to put America and its citizens ahead of their partisan interests.

Unfortunately, the Scott Walker wing of the party continues to prove that it cares hardly at all about America and Americans, and will do anything to please the wealthy special interests that pay to reelect them.

The "clear answer" in 2016 was that the voters preferred Clinton to Trump, by a margin of almost 3 million votes.

It's true that Republicans solidified their control of Congress in 2016. It's not clear that they could have done this without gerrymandering and voter IDs laws patently aimed at reducing the number of minority votes.

Come on, Gov. Walker.  If all power rested with the states, there would still be racial segregation in the schools of Alabama, uncontrolled oil spills in Texas, no national parks in Wyoming, and undrinkable water in places far beyond Flint, MI.  Why do people like you NEVER refer to the other side of the coin of states' rights--namely, the fact that it means freedom for some (often the few) at the expense of others (often the many)?

Wow, I wonder if Scott Walker is running for a third term. In addition to his "bold vision" discussed here to drug test prospective job hires, his bold vision over the last several years has consisted of destroying public and private unions, shredding environmental protections, and decimating funding for public schools. He has proposed a cynical new budget this year to add money back for public schools but this is likely just a ploy to bring up his approval ratings which have been in the dumpster for some time.  I suspect that despite all the political shennanigans, Scott Walker will become a referendum on the Donald and his similarly destructive policies. My guess is that in the end there will be a resounding rejection of both Trump, and Walker's "bold vision."

In my state, Republicans say they should have local control and freedom from the oppression of the Federal Government.

At same time, when a town votes to restrict guns or fracking, the state Republicans step in and pass laws saying the state has jurisdiction on these matters and the cities are prohibited from local control.

We all know it is just hypocrisy. Republicans are there just to take care of their wealthy donors.

SAD
It is always best to ignore your constituents' biggest concerns, Governor. Well said.
Walker has been dividing Wisconsinites his entire career. It's how he made his bones here. He has always been a Deplorable.

Standing firm on tax breaks to millionaires while starving state institutions that support your constituents is just greed and a complete lack of morals, empathy and dereliction of duty.

You are a complete fraud Gov. Walker...an empty suit doing the bidding of your donor masters as great cost to a great state.

Lots of hypocrisy here about lean government and local control.
Walker has denied local control of school budgets (limiting the amount Madison can spend on education), opposes local control of environmental rules, opposes local control of marijuana rules and has signed off on $450 million in taxpayer money to wealthy sports owners.

"Our founders" envisioned a country of white male landowners, Gov. Scott and I think you might be envisioning the same.

Take a closer look at those protesters--those so-called "liberals" aren't leaning so left. What I saw were some very down home folks who were very dependent on the ACA and saw the reality of a politically motivated repeal and carelessly put together replace.

Easy for all of these rich, mostly white, male Republicans with a great Congressional insurance plan to ignore the voices of the people they represent.

Maybe, you might want to repeal and replace the Constitution as well, Governor.

Scott,

Glad you could take the "high road," with protests. Maybe mention that to the President of Tweet; he's and embarrassment and you know it. What is even more sinister is the GOP supporter like yourselves. Not so much the "high road" as in the gutter and in the mud.
Let it go, John. And may someone show you mercy in your hour of need.
Long live the Pope. I don't claim to be a theologian but his messages almost always seem what would JESUS really do.

Pope Francis has worked to return the Catholic Church to its roots, but it has had almost two millennia in which to entrench its own concepts of entitlement, arrogance, and hypocrisy.

I have not doubt that Francis would desire a more rapid return to the tenets of their religion, but he is facing a bureaucracy that has far more to lose than most would care to imagine.
Elevating compassion over doctrine is also never wrong. For my part, it is THE doctrine. What else matters?
Why lie about the contacts?   Why commit perjury instead of acknowledge them. Manifort, Stone, Kushner are all totally corrupt.

That is a good general outline.

We could go further to offer demilitarization of Korea, and de-escalation around China. I am thinking of the Washington Naval Limitation Treaty work of 1921, that included an end to fortifications across a vast area, to keep the sides apart.

Follow the money then we'll see what's what. When Mr. Trump and his associates reveal their taxes and financial accounts a clearer picture will emerge. So far, they have hidden their financials and their meetings; this constitutes the smoke and the fire.  What the ambassador gets wrong in his assessment is that there may be financial entanglements, along with secret meetings, that have not been made transparent.

Mar-au-gogo is once again Trump's weekend destination and it becomes more obvious that he considers the Presidency to be his day job.

Nobody cares much about their day job.

I believe he doesn't want his returns released simply because they reveal that he's not a good businessman, either.

The issue that Russian  meddling in the US election process and Trump's complicity in it with treasonous malfeasance now looming as a real possibility doesn't matter?  What side of your toast do you butter in the morning?

We don't know if Trump colluded with the Russians, and we don't know if information provided in the dossier of the British MI6 agent is true.  Someone somewhere does know if it's true and we the American people have a right to know the truth.  An independent investigation is absolutely required to find out if we are being duped.  Anything less will leave a large number of people wondering what is going on.
